description: This is an introduction to topics in the security of computer systems and communication on networks of computers. The course covers four major areas: fundamentals of cryptography, security for communication protocols, security for operating systems and mobile programs, and security for electronic commerce. Sample specific topics include: passwords and offline attacks, DES, RSA, DSA, SHA, SSL, CBC, IPSec, SET, DDoS attacks, biometric authentication, PKI, smart cards, S/MIME, privacy on the Web, viruses, security models, wireless security, and sandboxing. Students will be expected to display knowledge of both theory and practice through written examinations and programming assignments.
name: COMP & NETWORK SEC

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to topics in the security of computer systems and communication on networks of computers. The course covers four major areas: fundamentals of cryptography, security for communication protocols, security for operating systems and mobile programs, and security for electronic commerce. Sample specific topics include: passwords and offline attacks, DES, RSA, DSA, SHA, SSL, CBC, IPSec, SET, DDoS attacks, biometric authentication, PKI, smart cards, S/MIME, privacy on the Web, viruses, security models, wireless security, and sandboxing. Students will be expected to display knowledge of both theory and practice through written examinations and programming assignments.

Students found the course material to be interesting, but thought the implementation suffered. Students thought lectures were not very useful or technical, but the assignments were worth the time.

Students found Professor Smith to be very responsive to questions outside of class. They also noted his tendency to wander during lectures and not covering his desired points.

Students enjoyed the readings for the course, but found that there was a disconnect between the assignments and the topics covered in class. TCOM 512 or equivalent is a required prerequisite and CIS 500 is recommended.
